Although each individual Harry Potter movie at this point had a lightly altered cast and style partially due to plot modifications and change of director there was a consolidated vision shared because of keeping the film format presentable to the target audience (Curiously, randoms from pretty much any social circle). The novels were never meant to adapt faithfully given their pop ambiance, and I've no problem in a director inserting their relevant spin, but when it becomes mired in capitalistic interests, as with this version, it alienates one from the franchise. I don't think I cared or payed attention much to the sequels following this one, for example, as evidently none of the primetime subject matter would be translated. And this one was moderately dark in origin, but still would've been interesting to see it given its due. Horribly miscast Radcliffe has always stood out as the unconvincing type among his two proficient peers anyway, and playing the waiting game for two years between each film just to await another "To be continued..." was getting pretty pointless. The one good thing about the other HPs usually condemned in cinema (Style over substance) is just as fun seeing toyed with here, and the international angle beckoning foreign actors adds a little more distinction, but Goblet of Fire is best left for the HP fanatics.

Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire delivers a dark, adventure driven film full of magic and mystery.  In this chapter of the saga Hogwarts hosts the Tri-Wizard Tournament, which promises "eternal glory" to the victor.  The cast gets a bit stronger with the additions of Brendan Gleeson and David Tennant; Gleeson in particular injects a lot of fun and humor with his character of Mad-Eye Moody.  Additionally, director Mike Newell is able to move the series into dark and dramatic territory while still retaining the magic and enchantment that made the series so compelling.  Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is an exciting and thrilling adventure full of action, mystery, and terror.

Being an adaptation of the Harry Potter book with probably the most material to work with, Goblet of Fire had a lot of work on its hands to include and cut out just the right amount to make an engrossing film. Although one-time director Mike Newell succeeds for the most part, they might have tried to put a little too much in here. It's not the best in the series, but it isn't bad either.

    After the dark and gloomy approach of the third installment (Prisoner of Azkaban) worked so well, the movie makers took it too heart. This movie starts off with a shot of a bunch of skulls and a snake coming out from one one of them. It only gets worse from there. This is easily the darkest Harry Potter, full of murky lighting, foggy scenery, and creepy music. Luckily, it fits the dark and twisting plot well.

    This time around, three wizarding schools are having a tournament where three chosen contenders must compete for the Triwizard cup. And, of course, Harry's name mysteriously also is chosen, making him the fourth contender (called champions here). Who put his name in the Goblet of Fire? The plot thickens. Just like the excellent third movie, this film is full of twists and turns, most of which that you can't see coming (unless you've read the book, of course). It's one of the more interesting plots in the series, but it is unfortunately brought down by the only big problem with the movie.

     Considering the book of which this movie is based is full of subplots, they had to be very careful what to cut out and what to keep. Although they did cut some things completely, like Hermione fighting for house-elf rights (good thing that wasn't in here), many things they started but did not truly wrap up. For instance, Rita Skeeter is introduced, but is never really wrapped up appropriately like she was in the novel. Also, we see Barty Crouch lying in the woods (dead?), but this is never explained either. And don't even get me started on the Moaning Myrtle in the bathtub scene. If they were willing to cut some of the extra things out, this could have been a better movie. 

      Besides this glaring problem, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is a good movie with plenty of excitement (specifically to do with the fight with the dragon). The acting is not a huge problem in this one, the special effects are great, and we get to see (SPOILER) Lord Voldemort for the first time. If only they could tighten the plot, this would be a great film. Even still, it's a good one.

Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is the fourth installment in the Harry Potter movie and book series and Mike Newell sits in the director's chair this time around. A tri-wizard tournament, a game where three students from wizarding schools around the globe must each face three deadly events, is taking place in Hogwarts. All seems good and well after three champions are chosen until Harry is mentioned as a fourth champion, who is underage to participate in the tournament, and must represent Hogwarts alongside Cedric Diggory while trying to find out who entered him in the tournament. Yet again, like the other Harry Potter movies, John Williams makes a fantastic contribution to the movie with his brilliant music along with the help of Patrick Doyle. The music really fits the mood of each scene and does a brilliant job of making each scene more emotional than it already is. One of the greatest things about Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is the performances as we see Harry, Ron and Hermione grow up and mature as the movies go on. Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint and Emma Watson improve their performances as each movie goes on and Twilight fans may be happy to see Robert Pattinson play Cedric Diggory, another Hogwarts champion. The performances from the cast were solid throughout, there's not one bad thing I could say about any of the actors or actresses as they all depicted their characters perfectly. The characters in Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire are brilliant and the movie really captures the personality of the characters in the book very well. As well as this being the start of when the Harry Potter franchise turns very dark and the characters start to grow up from children to teenagers, children will still like this for the magic and the humour, which once again lights up a little from the darkness of the movie.

The cinematography and camerawork involved in making Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is absolutely phenomenal as it's beautifully shot involving fantastic special effects and breath-taking locations. The creatures involved in the movie are great to look at and look very realistic, which adds to the wonder and imagination of this magical world. Chris Columbus had directed the first two Harry Potter years and Alfonso Cuaron directed the third (which is considered to be a favourite among Potter fans) but I think that Mike Newell did a magnificent job in directing this movie and from making a book adaptation stand out so well as a movie and an adaptation of the book. Although there is three things I am disappointed about and that is that Winky (a house-elf from the book) is not in the movie at all and Hermione doesn't do her campaign, S.P.E.W, which was a movement to gain basic rights for house-elves and I thought it was an important part of her character. I also thought that Albus Dumbledore didn't behave correctly like he did in the books, he was wise, calm and rational but in the movie, he was more angry. Except for those minor details, I believe that Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire was a great movie and is definitely a very welcome addition to the movie series.

Even though there's a few things missing from the book, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is a great adaptation and really captures the feeling and the mood of the book. It's unfortunate that there's sub-plots missing because, as a price, the character development and parts of the story were missing too. For me, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire and Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix are my favourite books and I think that the cast and crew have done a terrific job in making Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire. As the books go darker and more mature, so do the movies, however this could mean that some of the scenes in the movie might be too scary for a younger audience. If you want an adaptation that is one-hundred percent faithful to the book, then you will be disappointed as even though this is quite faithful, there's a few things missing. However, if you're a Potter fan and you like the movies for what they are, then this is for you.

Harry Potter is one of the best movie series ever! Harry Potter dreams of an elderly man, Frank Bryce, who overhears Lord Voldemort discussing plans with Peter "Wormtail" Pettigrew and Barty Crouch Jr. Frank is then killed by Voldemort. The Quidditch World Cup allows Harry to take his mind off his nightmares until followers of Voldemort known as Death Eaters terrorize the spectators' campsites after the match, and Crouch Jr. summons the Dark Mark, a sign showing that Voldemort is returning to power. At Hogwarts, headmaster Albus Dumbledore introduces ex-Auror Alastor "Mad-Eye" Moody as the new Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher. In their first Defence Against the Dark Arts lesson, the students learn of the three Unforgivable Curses. The Imperius Curse causes absence of free will, the Cruciatus Curse causes unbearable pain, and the final curse, Avada Kedavra, causes death. Dumbledore announces that the school will host the Triwizard Tournament, in which one wizard from each of the three magical schools competes in three challenges. The champions are selected by the Goblet of Fire, a magical cup into which the candidates' names are placed. Fred and George attempt to enter using an aging potion as no one under 17 can enter. This fails miserably. Cedric Diggory, a student from the House of Hufflepuff, is chosen to represent Hogwarts, Viktor Krum is chosen to represent Durmstrang Institute, and Fleur Delacour is selected to represent Beauxbatons Academy of Magic. The Goblet unexpectedly chooses a fourth champion: Harry. As Harry is underage and should have been ineligible to compete, Hogwarts teachers and students grow suspicious, and the feat drives Ron and Harry apart. The teachers want Dumbledore to pull Harry out of the tournament, but the four champions are bound by a magical contract and therefore Dumbledore has no choice and Harry must compete. For the first task of the Triwizard Tournament, each of the champions must retrieve a golden egg guarded by a dragon. Mad-Eye advises Harry to use his talent for flying to overcome the dragon. Harry enters the first task and summons his broomstick to retrieve the egg, which contains information about the second challenge. The students are soon informed of the Yule Ball, a Christmas Eve ball held during the Triwizard Tournament. Ron and Harry have trouble finding dates to the ball and when they find out that Hermione is attending with Viktor Krum, Ron becomes jealous. In exchange for previous aid, Cedric provides Harry with a clue that prompts him to open the egg underwater. With help from Moaning Myrtle, he learns that the second task entails the retrieval of "something precious" to each of the competitors from the nearby Black Lake, where there are mermaids. While preparing for the task, Neville Longbottom provides Harry with Gillyweed, enabling him to breathe underwater for one hour. Harry is the first to arrive at the location, and finds Ron, Hermione, Cho Chang and Fleur's sister, Gabrielle, in suspended animation. Finishing last after attempting to free Ron and Gabrielle, Harry is awarded second place for "outstanding moral fiber", behind Cedric. Following an exchange with Mad-Eye, Ministry official Barty Crouch, Sr. is found dead by Harry shortly after the second task. While waiting in Dumbledore's office, Harry's curiosity leads him to look into Dumbledore's pensieve, causing him to revisit one of Dumbledore's memories. He witnesses a trial before the Wizengamot in which captured Death Eater Igor Karkaroff, the current headmaster of Durmstrang, denounces a number of Death Eaters, including both Severus Snape and Barty Crouch Jr. While Dumbledore vouches for Snape's integrity, Crouch Sr. is horrified at this revelation and disowns his maniacal son, sending him to Azkaban. Upon returning to the present time, Dumbledore tells Harry that he is searching his memories for a clue as to why extraordinary events have taken place at Hogwarts since the start of the tournament. In the Triwizard Tournament's third and final task, the competitors are placed inside a hedge maze; their challenge is to reach the Triwizard Cup. Krum, acting under the Imperius curse, incapacitates Fleur and attempts to do the same to Cedric. Harry stops Cedric from attacking Krum, and the two run for the cup. When Cedric is trapped by vines, Harry frees him and the two claim a draw and grab hold of the cup together. The cup, which is a Portkey, transports the two champions to a graveyard where Wormtail and Voldemort are waiting for Harry. Wormtail murders Cedric, traps Harry, then performs a ritual that rejuvenates Voldemort, who then summons the Death Eaters (which includes Draco's father, Lucius) and bids them to witness a duel between their Dark Lord and his nemesis. As Harry, who is tortured by Voldemort, fights him, a connection called Priori Incantatem occurs between their wands. Harry's wand forces Voldemort's to disgorge the spirits of the people Voldemort has most recently murdered, including Harry's parents, Frank Bryce and Cedric. Harry is briefly protected by the spirits and escapes with Cedric's body (as his request) using the cup. Upon his return, Harry tells Dumbledore and Minister for Magic Cornelius Fudge that Voldemort has returned and is responsible for Cedric's death. That's the plot, and it's an amazing movie, full of action, adventure, and more, highly recommend.

'Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire' is the only one in the series I didn't go to see in the theater, so I eagerly waited to get it on DVD the first day it came out. In Which Doctor Who Returns Amon Goeth to Power  

I understand why they took out the whole house elf subplot.  And to be honest, SPEW got kind of annoying in places in the books.  But I think some of the changes in this one only served to make the later movies a bit more confusing to people who hadn't read the books.  No, we didn't necessarily need to know that Fleur Delacour (Clémence Poésy) was part veela; we didn't even need to know what veela are.  (Though you can find out by checking Wikipedia, and no, not just [i]Harry Potter[/i] entries.)  But was there a reason that the Weasley family plus guests are in the nosebleed seats at the Quidditch World Cup instead of being in the Top Box?  Other than to give Draco Malfoy (Tom Felton) another reason to sneer, of course.  Which he doesn't need, because he certainly found enough other reasons elsewhere in the story.  It also leaves out important character development for two other people who either are or are supposed to be in that box, meaning other plot is changed for no good reason.

Harry Potter (Daniel Radcliffe) is back for his fourth year at Hogwarts.  This year, Hogwarts will be hosting that ancient tradition, the Triwizard Tournament.  Students from the three great Wizarding schools of Europe will compete for the Triwizard Cup, and because no one under seventeen will be permitted to compete, Harry is quite looking forward to letting someone else face danger for a change.  Alas, the Goblet of Fire, which chooses the schools' champions, has been fooled into choosing Harry as a champion--and since putting your name in the Goblet is a binding magical contract, Harry must compete.  He is up against Fleur of Beauxbatons, Viktor Krum (Stanislav Ianseki) of Durmstrang, and Cedric Diggory (That Poor Boy), who had hoped to finally give Hufflepuff a chance for glory.  Watching over him, among the old familiar faces, is this year's new Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher, Mad-Eye Moody (Brendan Gleeson).

You know, Alfonso Cuarón apparently worked to convince Mike Newell that he could do the whole story in a single movie, and I don't think he did anyone any favours by it.  A lot of people were awfully smug about how the division of the seventh book into two movies was about money, but that simply wasn't the case.  Or anyway it wasn't the whole case.  The books, starting with this one, have a lot of story in them.  As I said, we [i]do[/i] leave out the whole SPEW subplot.  No one is credited as Ludo Bagman.  The Weasley twins (James and Oliver Phelps) lost a lot of plot development, and Percy simply isn't in the movie at all.  And Ron (Rupert Phelps) loses a lot of character development over the course of the series, much of which is in this segment of the story.  His relationship with Hermione (Emma Watson) loses some, but perhaps most of all is his relationship with Harry.  After all, for once, he had no reason to believe that Harry was going to upstage him, but it happened again.

The other really irritating thing is that it is yet another installment of the series where plot gives way in part for a too-long action sequence.  This seems to have been a fundamental misunderstanding on the part of someone; these aren't particularly action stories.  Never have been.  Things happen, but the things which happen aren't the most important part.  Many of the action scenes in the book take only a few pages; some of the practical precautions in them get ignored.  (In this case, the fact that the dragons are chained down so they don't, say, chase one of the students all over the area and get completely loose.)  The stories are about a boy's journey into manhood that just happens to be paired with a magical quest.  The stories are about people, not actions, and the movies have consistently missed that, though none of them quite so badly as [i]Chamber of Secrets[/i].  And indeed, that's part of why they worked so hard on the casting, which includes the majority of the great British actors.

Dyllan, who is currently a member--I kid you not--of his college's Quidditch team, wanted to be in these movies.  Desperately.  And because he's an actor, a lot of people would think he would have had a chance, at least as being one of the people wandering the halls of Hogwarts somewhere in the background.  However, it wasn't going to happen.  Similarly, IMDb is wrong when it suggests that people thought they were considering John Malkovich as Lord Voldemort.  Rowan Atkinson, possibly (though he wouldn't have done as well as Ralph Fiennes), but not John Malkovich.  Almost the entire cast of the movie was born somewhere in the British Isles, and if the actor wasn't, it was because the character wasn't.  For example, Predrag Bjelac, who played Karkaroff, was born in Belgrade.  But no, neither Dyllan nor John Malkovich ever had a chance.  And I'm quite pleased by that fact.  It's the thing the movies inarguably did right, even if this one features neither Dursleys nor Mrs. Weasley.

You'll laugh, you'll gasp, you'll cheer, you'll cry - Mike Newell really blew this movie out of the water, and has crafted one of my favorite films of all time. Dan, Rupert, and Emma completely knock their performances out of the park, giving some of the most emotionally resonant and passionate performances in their career, which makes them an absolute joy to watch on screen. While the absence of the Quidditch match in the beginning of the film is a little disappointing, the Triwizard Tournament more than makes up for it: it's easily the most exciting, tense, and downright amazing premise the world of Hogwarts has to offer. If that wasn't enough, the ending proves to be one of the most heart wrenching and epic finales of any fantasy film to date, complemented by stunning visual effects and a beautiful soundtrack (the rendition of Hedwig's theme for the opening titles still gives me chills to this day). While many won't recognize this as the best of the series, I believe that it takes the cake, with Deathly Hallows - Part 2 a close second. What an incredible fantasy film.

Well, here I am reviewing another Harry Potter film- Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire - trying to narrow down what makes them so entertaining.  Is it the story?  For while the story for the first film was a bit weak, they've certainly improved as the series continues.  Is it the characters?  I can complain all I like about how little screen time some of them get (and indeed, this problem plagues this chapter as well), but those complaints do stem from a love for the characters in the film.  Of course, there is the music, the visuals, and the storybook feel that all of the films seem to possess.  Flaws aside, the Harry Potter films have given me many reasons to return to Hogwarts, and Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is no exception.

The students of Hogwarts are anticipating the Triwizard Tournament, though they are dismayed that students under the age of 17 are not permitted to enter the tournament.  Despite this, Harry Potter is somehow selected to compete- even though he is not of the appropriate age.  A mystery now surrounds the tournament, and it's important that it be solved before any harm comes to Hogwarts.

Everything that has made the previous films so enjoyable is here in this film.  The characters are just as loveable as ever, and the new additions (specifically Rita Skeeter and Mad-Eye Moody) are excellent.  The visual effects are fantastic, and the overall story continues to develop.

There truly isn't much more to say that I haven't already said in my previous reviews of the Potter films.  Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is entertaining, well made, often exciting, often funny, and occasionally magical.

The acting is well done.  Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, and Emma Watson are growing more and more at home in their roles as Harry, Ron, and Hermione respectively.  Brendan Gleeson is fantastic as Mad-Eye Moody, and Miranda Richardson is hilarious as Rita Skeeter.

The most worthy of note, however, may just be the music, composed by Patrick Doyle.  While John Williams scored the previous three films, a change in composer still seemed like a refreshing idea.  And Doyle's score might just be the best Potter score thus far.  With a strikingly beautiful arrangement of Hedwig's theme at the very beginning, and many memorable cues that even those not listening to the score should notice, Doyle's score is a breath of fresh air from the already superb work by Williams.  The only problem that some might have, is that many of Williams themes are underused or omitted entirely, but Doyle's new additions to the score easily make up for this.

Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is fun, but also has substantial depth.  A delight to watch, and just as wonderful to listen to, this is exceptional fantasy entertainment.

Although I don't love it as much as the previous film, I must say "The Goblet of Fire" is pretty damn entertaining! It has the tone that is heavier, the vibe that feels more ominous, the story that is scarier and more mature than the previous 3 films, and it has this sense of dread throughout the film. But there is also a plenty of humor that works against more serious and poignant moments. It is superbly crafted and the set pieces are quite impressive, but the thing that makes this franchise special, timeless, and compelling is the characters. This is a franchise that evolves as its characters mature, and it makes it relatable for the audiences. It's kind of brilliant.

Was my favorite of the Potter flicks until a re-watching of the the entire series threw 3, 6 and 7.2 up there. But still I love this outing. "I Love Magic" Harry utters as he arrives at the Quidditch World Cup with 5 of the Weasleys and Hermione and sees at best a two person tent. However, inside are 4 bed areas, a kitchen, a dining area and a living area. And don't we all love it. This was has dragons, killer merpeople, a little sexual tension as these high schoolers mature to the point where they are completely aware thank girls are girls and boys are boys. The tension between Ron and Hermione that has been hinted at since the end of the first flick(awkward handshake anyone) is on full display here. As is a row between Ron and his famous Best friend. FIRE also has the distinction of introducing the world to Robert Pattinson as big man on campus Cedric Diggory and more importantly introduced the world the fully resurrected Lord Voldermort played with giddy menace by Ralph Finnes. Action packed, humorous and also featuring the first in many shocking deaths to come. Harry just keeps on getting on better.

Director Mike Newell throws Chris Colmbus and Alfonso Cuaron's previous work into the shadows with a masterful adaption of JK Rowling's fourth Potter tale.

While it's fair to say that the first three were very good films, Newell's take on the Goblet of Fire takes the franchise upto new heights. 

What the film does differently is creates mystery but combines that with action and excitement so that viewers will barely feel a dull moment. Previously in Potter universe, we've had some great Sherlock Holmes style invetsigations occurring such as, who really is Sirius Black and how do you get into the Chamber of Secrets. This was perfectly acceptable but the continous regime was beginning to become repeitive. Don't get me wrong, Iam a big mystery solver/who dunnit fan but Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire's action and entertainment aspects were what made it so delightful and intriguing to watch.

The movies pace is so fast that the Dursley's have been axed from its opening and instead we witness a suspeseful if unresolved nightmare from within Harry's head of an old person being killed after glaring at a mysterious alien type figure, a man with a black cloak (David Tennant), Wormtail (Timothy Spall) and a vicious snake.

Immediatly this sets the scene for some detective work but not before Harry and the gang are attacked by a host of Death Eaters. The man with the black clock (Tennant) then appears on a deserted battlefield some time later, unaware of Harry's presence before disappearing.

However, bigger problems eveolve for Harry when he is unwittingly picked for a tournament under his age limit. He faces a fire breathing dragon in one of three extremely dangerous tasks. 

Not to give too much away, Harry Potter four is the best of the first four movies and a brilliant watch. It evades five stars by the skin of its teeth; there were just a few things the film lacked which I can't quite put my finger on. But nevertheless, open your Gob and either get the DVD or movie tickets; don't throw your hopes in the fire!

A good "Harry Potter" film; confident, capable, exciting, entertaining, and fun.  Harry teams up with fellow Hogwarts student Cedric Digory to enroll in the Tri-Wizard Tournament, a round-by-round battle to see who is the best wizard in the three districts of Wizard Schools.  But there's something about this tournament that bothers Harry.  Something that reinvokes his memory of his parents, and reinvigorates his fear of Voldemort also...  the story is driven, purposeful, and well-made.  The movie feels what an adaptation should feel like; taking all of the important parts of the novel, putting it in script format, and make it work on the big screen in the same effective manner.  This film is effective in its portrayal of "Harry Potter".  The acting is good, the visual effects are fantastic, and this is by far one of the better adaptations of the "Harry Potter" franchise.  Again, the film leaves you with an ending that is dissatisfying and somewhat cliche, but the film also leaves a cliffhanger, making the viewer desperate to find out what will happen next.

Book-wise, i i like it better than the first three, i was even able to get past how Dumbledore didn't realize Voldemort's plot until it was already too late, but movie-wise, not quite as good as the first three. it was entertaining to watch, but it missed much of what i liked in the books, like the scene with the Dursley's at the beginning (always great to see what happens to them in the books), the actual playing of the Quidditch World Cup, and Dumbledore as usual in the books.

Just like in the first three, great cast with great newcomers (Brendan Gleeson as Moody, Robert Pattison as Cedric, who actually did a great job, mainly at the end when he dies, and the only reason i gave it a 70 and not lower, Ralph Fiennes as Voldemort). I once again dispised the choice of Michael Gambon as Dumbledore, but this time, he actually did something that just got me outraged, (although it wasn't until after i read the book and rewatched the movie that i felt this rage, before then, i was fine with it), HE MANHANDLED HARRY. DUMBLEDORE WOULD NEVER DO THAT TO A STUDENT, THERE IS A SCENE IN ORDER OF THE PHOENIX (obviously not in the movie) WHERE UMBRIDGE MANHANDLES A STUDENT AND DUMBLEDORE FINALLY STOPS SMILING AND ZAPS HER IN ANGER!!!!!!!! WHY DID ROWLING PERMIT THAT!!!!!!!! But everyone else was fine.

I didn't like what they did with the three tasks in the movie, i prefer how it was done in the book better

in the first task in the book, Harry uses his firebolt to get the dragon to fly, and then ducks down and grab the egg when it was up in the air. I understand why they didn't put it in the movie, but i'm sure they could've came up with a more thrilling, yet believable way of doing it, i mean, the teachers would've done something if the dragon had broken free of it's chain, but no, they wanted to make it look entertaining, not think of a different entertaining sequence.

in the second task in the book, the egg said the hostages would die to motivate the champions, like they'd actually kill the little 8 year old girl Fleur couldn't save, that's what actually made the scene great, but in the movie, they should've just stuck with the book, because it was actually funny to find that he didn't necessarily have to save the girl.

the third task is easily the most messed up of the tasks, if you read the book, it's actually a better, and more dangerous maze than in the movie, instead of the maze walls trying to grab you, there and monsters out there that make it more thrilling, and the end of the third task in the movie was just flat out stupid, in fact, i thought the book did a more dramatic job than the movie on how the two decide to take it together, how the two actually argued with each other on who should take it instead of choosing to do it in order to save both lives.

The opening part of the graveyard sequence with Wormtail and the process of turning Voldemort back into Voldemort was scary when i first saw it when it came on DVD, and why not, i was only 8 when i saw it, but after reading the book, i didn't think it was THAT scary compared to how scary it was in the book.

But what makes the graveyard sequence so scary in the movie is when we're finally introduced to Ralph Fiennes as Voldemort. This is what totally redeems the movie from all of the bagging i've been giving it. This was the moment Fiennes BECAME Voldemort, and the graveyard scene will always be one of the most memorable scenes in the Harry Potter movie series.

i didn't see it in theaters because of the whole PG-13 thing, but that was around the time when i should just suck it up and do it, so i bought it instead. And shortly afterwards, i read the first six books and had to wait for seven to come out. and i rewatched the first four movies after reading each. This one was OK, but the book was TOTALLY better, and it was Ralph Fiennes as Voldemort that saved the movie for me.

The fourth entry into the Harry Potter Saga is really epic because it's more complex. Hogwarts is visited by other schools to participating in the Triwizard Tournament, a tournament in which each student of their own school gets to participate 3 difficult challenges. They are chosen by the Goblet of Fire. But it seems that the goblet has chosen 4 champions, including Harry Potter. Everybody thinks that Harry put his name on the Goblet, but if it wasn't him, who was? Could Lord Voldemort be up to something? As the film progresses it shows that not everyone is your friend in the magic world. 
The film is like nothing you have ever seen. From the production design, set design, the art direction, the costume design, and the visual effects all of those things are perfect in this movie. The film is bright and yet dark at the same time. Finally after the three movies we get to finally see Lord Voldemort, and he is frightening. The make-up put on this Ralph Fiennes is really impressive, pale like if he was a ghost. I basically love the graveyard scene because we finally get to see the battle between good and evil. Another theme played in this movie is about friendship, how to keep your old friends while making some new friends. I seriously loved the jealously on Ronald's face when Hermione is dancing with another guy. I also love the usual morality of the story about love is beyond death and that nothing can stop love, not even evil. As an entertainment movie is really classic, because I didn't get bored with this movie. The pacing of this movie is really great, fast and it doesn't slow you down. The performance of Brendan Glenson's performance as Professor Mood was cool and funny, especially when he turns Malfoy into a rat. Miranda's performance as Rita Skeeter was also cool and a little bit malevolent in what she wants to write it in her own way. The acting of the kids in this movie was generally better than the previous instalments especially when one of the champions dies and Harry is weeping you feel kind of sad for them. The cinematography worked great in this movie, especially on the scenes of the challenges, it worked really cool. 
There's nothing bad I can say of this movie except there was some things that were left unexplained in the movie.  For example when Harry tells Dumbledore about his confrontation with Voldemort, Dumbledore simply says "Priori Incantantem" but he doesn't explain what that is. I know that the book explains it to you but I think Dumbledore in the movie could say something about it. Now I did liked and enjoyed the soundtrack of the movie, but I kind of feel bad that they replaced John Williams. I mean John Williams is one of the greatest composers of all time, and you replacing him from the Harry Potter Franchise are like replacing the lead actors, because John is an important ingredient in this franchise believe it or not. 
The film was directed by Mike Newell and this is his only Harry Potter directed film. He is most famous for this movie. In January 2006, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire surpassed the box office takings of Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets, to become the eighth highest-grossing film worldwide at the time, and the second highest-grossing film in the Harry Potter series, behind Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone. As of July 2011 it is the sixth highest-grossing Harry Potter film behind The Philosopher's Stone, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix and Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 and Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2. 
The film ranks third in the North American box office behind Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith and The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe for 2005, although both films rank lower than Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire in worldwide terms.
I recommend this movie to people that love fantasy films, people that enjoy adventure films, to people that love an action-family movie this movie is for you guys. I think this is the best in the Harry Potter franchise because is both colourful and dark. An excitement that would never be forgotten.

The best of the Harry Potter series! Truly an excellent film! Even as we go into the two part 7th and final chapter of the Harry Potter series, I still give the top prize to Mike Newell's Goblet of Fire. Why? This is clearly the definitive moment in the Potter series where the series walks away from being a children's story and transitions into a much darker story, while still delivering more fun and excitement of an epic adventure than any of the other Potter films. The actors in Goblet of Fire give their best and most realistic performances. Harry moves into a deeper and more complex world, the world of dating. Harry Potter, the boy who can fly on broomsticks, fight dragons, battle dark lords, without fear or hesitation. Yet, he is terrified to simply ask a girl to the school's dance. Innocence now begins to fade, dark and difficult are truly approaching. These themes and characteristics are magically well constructed and crafted in the film's story and presentation that I never in a million years expected a Harry Potter film to reach this level of entertainment and this level of brilliant filmmaking. For me this is The Empire Strikes Back of the Harry Potter series. It is a shame that HP 5 and HP 6 didn't even come close to Goblet, now it's up to HP 7. Goblet of Fire reins as the best of the Potter series, and was even one of my top ten films of 2005, and believe me that is saying a lot.

Mike Newell's "The Goblet of Fire" is a thrilling, action-packed and moving film that does a satisfactory job of adapting the book. The fourth entry in the "Harry Potter" series deviates considerably from the book in terms of content. However, it offers sheer entertainment-value that fans of the novel won't be able to resist. Using gorgeous production values, Newell draws viewers into the three dangerous tasks of the Triwizard Tournament. From the heart-pounding dragon chase to the mesmerizing underwater sequence, the fantastic action sequences raise the stakes considerably. Yet, while "The Goblet of Fire" offers plenty of thrilling action, it often loses sight of the story. The script awkwardly rushes past important events in the book, which can at times be confusing for newcomers to the series. That being said, the excellent performances from the cast keep this blockbuster from falling apart. The golden trio- Radcliffe, Watson and Grint- are astonishing and demonstrate how far they have matured as actors. The supporting players- including the scene-stealing Brendan Gleeson- are also perfectly cast and get the chance to shine. At nearly three hours, "The Goblet of Fire" is undeniably overlong and often tests the viewer's patience. Nevertheless, fans of the beloved series will definitely enjoy it and so will movie-goers seeking exhilarating entertainment. As a long-time fan of the series, I did not enjoy the movie initially but have come to appreciate it more upon re-viewing. Even if it's not flawless, it's well worth a watch for Potter fans.

Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is a masterful and dark entry to this series, and is right behind the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 as the best Potter film.  This movie does everything great, it darkens the mood knowing that the fans and actors are getting more mature and wanting something better.  I mean every scene is just pure genius from the music or to the acting, but I just love howintense this film is.  The plot gets darker and better as we watch, and the finale of the film is one of the defining moments of the franchise.  I also love how they are able to make sure these characters are growing up, instead of keeping them as the kids they were in the first three.  The cast gives some of the finest performances I have seen in the franchise, I mean the three main heroes are just mesmorizing in their roles while they handle playing more mature characters now.  I also want to give credit to the three challenges, the dragon scene, the underwater scene, and the maze were all such brilliant filmmaking and I must give credit to the direction for that.  I love this film with a passion, and is by far my second favorite of the entire series.

The Goblet of Fire, well i could never get on with the book so at least i can see it visualized. I remember feeling pretty disappointed with every Harry Potter movie after Azkaban, this one especially but in hindsight i was probably being a little too tough on it. My extra years since then on Earth have taught me to just forget the book. The spirit of the source material is all here. Again i must congratulate the majority of the cast - I can't get over Alan Rickman's Snape! Michael Gambon's Albus Dumbledore seems to be too angry and short for my liking though. All of the tasks are quite fun i guess, and i really enjoyed the beginning with the Weasley's. Goblet also sees a hint of teenage hormones blossoming too which is quite amusing, really. Everything here pretty much hits the mark, i guess it's inevitable that i'll cringe at some of the dialogue, and i also feel that i'm somewhat more accommodating towards the more 'off' parts of this, as a fan of the Harry Potter series. In conclusion, The Goblet of Fire does what it needs to do to move the story along the more darker route and it delivers some great humor with it too. As expected the majority of the supporting cast are just a pleasure to watch as they interact with each other but i can't help but feel that Daniel Radcliffe & Rupert Grint are perhaps the weakest links at times.
Of course, it's obvious it can possibly continue it's series, with new artful directors, and more flashes, Harry Potter really rocks.

Due to its enormous 734 pages, J.K. Rowling's fourth book is quite difficult to put into a 157-minute film.  That's five pages a minute, and in that state, nothing can sink in any more than Dumbledore's speech at the end could sink into the Hogwarts students' minds.  New director Mike Newell used the different technique of skipping over large unnecessary parts in the book and filling up the spare space with action scenes.  As a result, the film isn't nearly as entertaining as its source material, and I would advise that you just leave it and read the book first.

Apart from the last film, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is the greatest action-packed film of the series.  Highlights include the First Task with the Firebolt, the introduction to the Quidditch match and the final graveyard scene.  However, there are still several flaws.  The beginning is far to rushed, perhaps because of the incredible length of the source material.  The Dursleys do not even show up in the film and the Quidditch match is cut abruptly short.  Much of the backstory of different characters are either omitted or underexplained.  When the movie is not in action, it tends to drag a bit, including some rather pointless fillers.  However, once the film reaches the climax, the audience will forget about the flaws and stare mesmerized at the awakening of Lord Voldemort.

Watch out, kids, because this installment is actually rated PG-13, so you know that things are about to get real, something that I'm kind of hoping Harry Potter's hair in this film isn't. No, it's not that bad, but the point is that Harry is really getting into the teen years, and let me tell you, that big head of long hair and a small head doesn't exactly make it easy to take his particular teen problems all that interesting. Well, I don't even know if this supposedly more serious installment in the "Harry Potter" saga makes Lord Voldemort all that intimidating, because that killing spell, "Avada Kedavra", that he blurts out sounds too much like the trite "abra cadabra" sorcerery for him to not silly. Well, in this film, you do actually get to see him in his realized form, and at that point, he's so creepy that I'd be intimidated by him performing "Witch Doctor", although that might simply be because Cartoons' cover is scary enough already. No, this film takes itself too seriously for that, so much so that it's starting to take its being British pretty seriously, to the point of going completely crazy and having the audacity to get... [u]a British director[/u]. I mean, at this point, this series only had two directors, so you wouldn't figure that it would be all that big of a deal, but one of those directors was Mexican, and once you're reaching for that group, you must have exhausted searches for the right hands, something that this series definitely found with Mike Newman... for only one film. Oh well, at least they followed him up with David Yates, who, I'm not going to lie, is a much better filmmaker than Newman, for although this film is awesome, Harry's hair and the names of certain killing spells aren't the only things shaking your investment here.

"The Prisoner of Azkaban" saw the formula that this series established starting to water down with its uniqueness, and with this film, familiarity is even more glaring, not so much in the context of a "Harry Potter" installment, - seeing as how this is a distinguished, if a touch formulaic point in the saga - but in a general context which sees this drama hitting many of the usual beat and path one might expect a blockbuster of this nature to hit. Still, no matter how familiar, the film stands to associate you more with its narrative, being a little more well-rounded as an ensemble piece, yet still with some underexploration of certain prominent plotting aspects and characters, which at least seem disconcerting because of forced rushing that slam-bangs certain happenings, - particularly others' interpretation on the games and other matters - and thins out some of the layers of this epic. Seeing as how the final product, through all of its underdevelopment and awkward hurried moments, runs well over a hefty runtime of two-and-a-half hours, it might go without saying that this drama tries to make up for attributes that are too tight for their own good, and too much so, shaking focal coherency with filler, - particularly with the near-inconsequential "Yule Ball" segment - and getting excessive with material to the point of meandering. There's only so much action to this pseudo-blockbuster, and inspiration certainly makes the film dramatically engrossing when it's a little less than pure, unadulterated fun, but the limited goings-on produce about as much a sense of aimlessness as they do a sense of dramatic thoughtfulness, and that might very well be because the subtlety upon which dramatic value thrives has a tendency to go shaken by subtlety issues. At this point, alone, the series was making near-remarkable progress in putting more edge and maturity to its storytelling, and the final product's being inspired to the point of bona fide dramatic excellence firmly reflects that, but for only so long, as the film can't completely wash away the cheese, not just in filler that sometimes gets to be too, not so much kiddy, but teeny for comfort, but to dramatics that, while never cloying, get kind of heavy-handed in a reflection of overambition. Many have debated the degree to which this film compensates for its messy moments of too much ambition, if not a hint of laziness, with inspiration, and for me, I must admit that the heart placed into the crafting of this effort keeps the final product pumping a long, long way on the whole, but stiffened a bit by familiarity, uneven pacing and subtlety issues which greatly threaten to hold the final product just shy of its final state of quality. Of course, I don't reckon you're in too bad of a place if you fall just short of excellent, and yet, the point is that the final product does, in fact, transcend its shortcomings enough to be the first in this solid saga to achieve excellence, and with no small help from aesthetic value.

Ostensibly looking to explore its British musical roots a little more, this film sees the series abandoning the great John Williams for Scottish composer Patrick Doyle, whose score gets a little too close to Williams' musical themes for the comfort of originality, but still offers plenty of weight that is tonally fitting, with a solid hint of aesthetic value that Roger Pratt expands upon with cinematography that is not only ruggedly handsome in its grit, but sweeping in scale. This scope certainly compliments the grandly well-staged action sequences, in addition to lively visuals that art directors Alan Gilmore, Andrew Ackland-Snow, Neil Lamont, Gary Tomkins, Alexandra Walker, Mark Bartholomew and Alastair Bullock build absolutely lavishly, with the help of intricate set designs by Stuart Craig, lovely costume designs by Jany Temime, and stellar visual effects, many of which aren't simply there for the sheer visceral spectacle that the preceding blockbusters seemed to primarily focus upon as technical triumphs. The effects are just as prominent as the art direction in the building of a distinguished world and the breathing of some life into deeper aspects of this whimsical narrative, yet they aren't quite as directly complimentary to the substance of this drama as the performances, all of which are memorable, with standouts in the supporting cast including the very underused, but effectively antagonistic Ralph Fiennes as the realized form of Lord Voldemort, and the delightfully charismatic and chillingly convincing Brandon Gleeson as an experienced sorcerer whose sanity and moral stances are questionable, while Daniel Radcliffe continues to do about as much as anyone or anything in making an intriguing lead character, with subtle charm and a few endearing dramatic layers. Boasting just as much, if not more stylistic proficiency than any of its predecessors, this film stands out as a blockbuster, alone, with acting that, while not exactly outstanding, helps greatly in placing some substance to go with style, and yet, it's debatable if this film improves upon the aesthetic, technical and acting value from, at the very least, "The Prisoner of Azkaban", which wouldn't have been so engrossing if it wasn't so technically sharp and well-acted. In terms of story concept, there was still something a little minimalist about "The Prisoner of Azkaban" that kept excellence at bay, thus, it's the narrative that really causes this film to stand out, not just ahead of its predecessors, but as excellent, because even though this story isn't exactly all that original, it is rich with layers of thorough color as an offbeat piece of teen fluff, in addition to liveliness as a portrayal of a competitive game, and, of course, tension as a near-gritty dramatic study on morality and encroaching dangers. Something of an epic, this film's particularly layered story concept carries a lot of potential, and although the execution has its faults in pacing, subtlety and altogether meeting ambition with inspiration, it does such potential a lot of justice more often than not, with Steve Kloves turning in a script whose wit and relatively greater exploration of supporting characters provides a color that director Mike Newell brings to life with very entertainingly brisk pacing, and whose more realized moments of dramatic weight are drawn upon by thoughtfulness to Newell's direction that make the tense aspects biting and the more sentimental aspects genuinely moving. Smoothly flowing from intensity, to considerable resonance, both of which reinforce a sense of consequentiality that in turn defines how far this series had come along in its maturity as an epic saga, the final act particularly excels in this film, but it is not much more than a height in compellingness that stands consistently throughout the final product, backed by a realization that is difficult to fully describe, and establishes enough style and substance to make a final product so entertaining, layered, and dramatically intriguing that it truly stands out.

In conclusion, formulaic and often underdeveloped storytelling reflects a certain laziness, while certain excesses in storytelling and subtlety issues reflect too great of an ambition to achieve excellence, ultimately secured by colorful scoring, handsome cinematography, thrilling action, immersive art direction and effects, charismatic acting and inspired writing and direction so effective in marrying thorough color with engrossing depth that "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" ultimately stands out as a triumph in blockbuster filmmaking whose entertainment value and dramatic range craft a truly excellent turn for the classic fantasy saga.

Humorous, exciting, with some admirable performances (Ralph Fiennes) and some impressive scenes (the graveyard scene), Goblet of Fire is dark, complex and solidly adapted, but at the same time, this is the film in the series where they started to go wrong, with some stupid and unbelievably retarded scenes, despicable changes from the source material and many plot holes.

In my opinion, this is one of the weakest of the Harry Potter films.  This is odd because it actually has my favorite living actress in it (Miranda Richardson).  This is the one Harry Potter movie where too much happens.  This film spits scene after scene at the viewer and expects us to come away satisfied that the story has been furthered.  Also, the performances suffer a bit.  While the acting generally can pull the somewhat weak story up to become something other than a dark picture, this movie just doesn't cut it.  Michael Gambon was unimpressive, Miranda Richardson was sadly underused but her performance was good.  The climax of this film is another area that it excels.  It is a strong climax where Ralph Fiennes really shines as a manic Voldemort that has Harry trapped in a net wanting to do so much and yet not wanting to waste the opportunity.  The overall weakness is the amount of things that were changed or left out from the book.  Anyway, this film is weak, but you can't really skip it.  It isn't worth skipping either.  There are some genuinely good parts of the movie, but the casual viewer might find the film frantic upon a first viewing and somewhat annoying on the subsequent ones.  Also, the bad level here is the highest the series has to offer with not even some good performances to catch the viewers eye and make them pay attention to anything other than the scene that starts moments later.

I'm a fan of the Harry Potter books. But as far as the movies go, most of them could have been done a lot better. This is one such example. The Goblet of Fire is poorly edited, crammed and rushed, and lacks much of the magic of the book. Still, Rowling's story can't be overlooked, and it carries this film. But it could have been a lot better.

I wasn't really excited at all going into Harry Potter & the Goblet Of Fire.  I had already watched 3 films, none of which really impressed me or kept me wanting more, but for some reason I soldiered on, maybe just out of sheer curiosity ot maybe just because I felt like I'd gotten far enough that I had to go all the way.  Well I'm definitely glad I did because Harry Potter & The Goblet Of Fire is a great movie.  Not only does it have all the technical wizardry of the first films that imrpessed me so much, but for once I was actually genuinely entertained by the story and actually enjoyed myself.

Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is the fourth year of Harry's time at the Hogworts School of Witchcraft & Wizardry, and the film appropriately works with the fact that he's growing up.  This film in particular concerns itself with the Tri-Wizard cup, an international wizardry tournament being held at Hogworts this year to determine the worlds best student wizard, and which of course Harry enters, not by his own will though.  Right off the bat the thing that impressed me was just how entertaining it was on its own.  For once the movie didn't just feel like it was pointlessly adding stuff in just to make it seem like a chapter of a larger story, it actually works as a film by itself.  This makes it work better as a film altogether, and makes for a much more entertaining plot.  What's great though is that it somehow does still contribute to the overall story.  It finally brings us Voldemort, the real Voldemort finally, and introduced many of the demons Harry will have to face later on.  It's sort of odd how the only way I can describe the movie contradicts itself, but it just kind of does, but somehow it works more successfully than any of the previous films.

Another real strength The Goblet Of Fire has is how it treats its characters, now aging and likewise maturing.  The film deals with many of the problems teenagers face in reality, such as love, betrayal, and the importance of friendship that ultimately ends up making it more deep, more comples, but most importantly highly relateable.  From this relateability it actually makes the characters seem more real and it actually gives you a better appreciation for them, as well as a better understanding.

This really helps make Harry Potter a more serious film, something I thought the others had a big problem with, they were just sort of silly little kid movies, and the big problem with the third film was that it was a little too serious, it was downright dark and at times a little depressing.  This one really hits the perfect note though, it keeps the characters serious, but keeps the story fun and entertaining, like this type of fantasy adventure should be.

One thing I still praise the living hell out of this series is that it always has the exact same people.  Not only does it make it easier for the viewer to keep track of who's who, but it really gives the actors time to grow into their roles and really perfect them, and in my opinion this is where the young actors truly did that.  Daniel Radcliffe is perfect as the always troubled Harry, bringing new emotion to a character that previously lacked a lot of it, again thanks to the improved character.  Rupert Grint is great as Ron, and seeing him grow has been fairly interesting, especially his changing relationship with Hermoine, played perfectly by Emma Watson who also gets a chance to shine with the films big love story.  For the first time wel also see the real Voldemort, now played by Ralph Fiennes.  He's a talented actor and looks prett badass as the character (although the fact that he doesn't have a nose is kind of off), but he isn't really in it enough to show us his stuff, that will have to wait.  Also appearing is Robert Pattinson of Twilight fame as one of Harry's tri-wizard cup opponents (I wonder how Stephen King feels about that knowing his love for Potter and hatred of Twilight).  He actually does a decent job, I was surprised.  I've never seen Twilight but from what I understand there is nothing good to say about it!

As with any long running series, the effects and technology will obviously improve as time goes on and The Goblet Of Fire is no excepetion.  It's by far the best looking Harry Potter yet in terms of its effects, but also uses them to better advantage.  Many of the scenes involving the competition for the Tri-wizard cup show off the effects perfectly, but the scene that stole the show for me was Harry's flying duel with the dragon which looked terrific and miles better than the flying sequences of the previous films.  The final battle with Voldemort also looks fantastic and has a certain eerieness to it that I like, finally a fitting appearence for the villain we've been hearing so much about.

The Goblet Of Fire featured yet again another director for the franchise, this time by the name of Mike Newell.  Not only does he capture all of the action in drama in a way that is both fun and suitably magical, but he also just nails the vibe of the whole movie, and makes it feel the way it should be.  The best thing I think he really did for the series was help transition it from the child-oriented adventures of the early films to the dark, serious epics of the later films, doing it seemlessly and making it feel appropriate that with Voldemort now here, everything has changed.

The Goblet Of Fire really is the turning point of the series.  It's when just about everything improved, from the obvious things like effects and sets, to the character's emotions, ths story, and the overall tone.  It's the finest and deepest film of the series yet, and in my opinion by far the best so far.  It really changed my mind about what the series could do, and I look forward to later installments because of it.

I was disappointed to find that Prisoner of Azkaban director Alfonso Cuaron didn't continue and make another Potter film, but alas, you can't win them all. Instead, we get director Mike Newell, who really hasn't done many films of consequence, not until this one at least. What impressed me the most was how Newell preserved the dark tone set by Alfonso Cuaron in the previous film. It's just as dark as before, and we even get to see an on-screen death, which may seem shocking to those who enjoyed Chris Columbus' childish Potter films, which were quite tame and dull. The story is just as mature as the previous, with enough hilarious and emotionally deep moments to carry the audience through the film. The acting is just as good as it was before, and the cinematography is good, but not as great as in the previous installment. It may not rank as high as Prisoner of Azkaban, but it's still a great addition to the series.

As an adaptation of the book this is probably the weakest of all the films. Mike Newell's take on Rowling's mammoth novel is darker and more action packed than its predecessors, but ultimately too episodic and lacking in heart. If there was an entry in the series that really warranted being split into two films it was this one; the executive decision to cut not only every subplot in the book, but also some of its most memorable events (the Quidditch World Cup) is almost disasterous. The film is essentially one action set piece after another, leaving little room for the artistic flair shown in Cuaron's Azkaban, or the more whimsical moments between the lead trio we've grown accustomed to. In the film's defense there are some brilliant moments; the battle with the dragon, the Yule Ball, and of course the rebirth of Voldemort remains the scariest moment in the entire series. Ralph Fiennes is an inspired casting choice for the Dark Lord, while Brendan Gleeson is also a great addition as Mad Eye Moody. Overall a solid flick in terms of action and spectacle, but if I could ask for a do-over of any of the movies, it would have to be this one.

Goblet Of Fire is my second favorite out of all 7. This one is about how Hogwarts is having the "Tri-wizard Tournament" which is a tournament of 3 matches. But the only thing is that you have to be a certain age to be able to put your name in the cup, which is i think 18. & somehow Harry's name gets put in the cup. & everyone in his year get kind of mad because he would get to & they wouldn't. So mad that even his BFF, Ron goes against him for a bit. Anyways so he has to do the tournament with 3 other people. Cedric Diggory (a new Robert Pattinson), Viktor Krum, & Fleur Detor. The first thing you have to do is pick a dragon out of a bag & which ever dragon you pick you go against the bigger version. & you have to get an egg from underneath the dragon, that's why you get a broom. Once you get the egg it reveals a secret to your next match. Which is you have to go down into the Black Lake, which has evil mermaids with sharp triton things. I have to be honest; this is the first review I have written where I wonder if I can be truly unbiased when evaluating its merit. There are two problems with me reviewing this movie. One is that I am so close to the source material, this book in particular, in my head it's hard to separate one from the other and it's difficult not to compare the two. Another problem is that I've seen this movie so many times over the years that honestly it's less a movie and more a part of my life and who I am. Now that I have that out of the way I will try and be objective in my evaluation of this movie as a film, not as a part of my childhood. This movie is probably my second favorite of the entire series, trumped only by the final eighth film. I love the story of the Tri-Wizard Tournament and though some of the intricacies are lost in the film it's a real turning point for the series. Since this is my first Harry Potter review I'll touch on the acting. Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, and Emma Watson are all absolutely perfect in their respective roles. These three young actors are a once in a lifetime find. They fit their roles perfectly and have grown from cute kids to excellent young adult actors. If a remake was ever made of this franchise the director would likely not be able to strike gold again. Now that I've touched on the main characters I'll move on to the supporting cast. First of all let me just list them: Alan Rickman, Maggie Smith, Michael Gambon, Brendan Gleeson, Ralph Finnes, Robbie Coltrane, David Tennant, Gary Oldman, Timothy Spall, and Warwick Davis. These are some of the greatest English actors around right now, and they are all here in top form. This supporting cast really speaks to how truly magical this series is. All of these top English thespians gladly giving their talents really shows how great of a world J.K. Rowling has created. I can gush about this movie and series all day long, but I really don't know how to convey why it's special unless you just know. I haven't touched on the writing or directing because honestly I don't really notice it at this point, neither is distracting so I guess there's that. The visual effects for this movie are pretty damn impressive especially considering it came out almost ten years ago. The dragons, mermaids, ghosts, flying horses, and most impressively the makeup done on human-esque creatures like Voldemort, or goblins all look great. Obviously I'm a Potterhead, and a proud one too so these films are very special to me and despite their flaws, I will never not love them.

EDITED

Directed by Mike Newell, the fourth installment to the Harry Potter series finds Harry (Daniel Radcliffe) wondering why his legendary scar -- the famous result of a death curse gone wrong -- is aching in pain, and perhaps even causing mysterious visions. Before he can think too much about it, however, Harry boards the train to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, where he will attend his fourth year of magical education. Shortly after his reunion with his best friends, Ron (Rupert Grint) and Hermione (Emma Watson), Harry is introduced to yet another Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher: the grizzled Mad-Eye Moody (Brendan Gleeson), a former dark wizard catcher who agreed to take on the infamous "DADA" professorship as a personal favor to Headmaster Dumbledore (Michael Gambon). Of course, Harry's wishes for an uneventful school year are almost immediately shattered when he is unexpectedly chosen, along with fellow student Cedric Diggory (Robert Pattinson), as Hogwarts' representative in the Tri-Wizard Tournament, which awards whoever completes three magical tasks the most skillfully with a thousand-galleon purse and the admiration of the international wizard community. As difficult as it is to deal with his schoolwork, friendships, and the tournament at the same time (not to mention his feelings toward the ever unfathomable Professor Snape (Alan Rickman), Harry doesn't realize that the most feared wizard in the world, Lord Voldemort, is anticipating the tournament, as well.

I used to hate Goblet of Fire for its absolute butchering of the uniquely crafted fourth book, which is Rowling's crucial bridge between the rich, layered world of Harry's adventure days and the dark atmosphere of impending doom that dominates the remainder of the books. The angst is the most painful here, and the entire chunk between the first and second trials  - namely the leadup and the Yule Ball itself - are awkward, painful and underwhelming - this may accurately portray the awkwardness of puberty but such things are better relegated to subtle sequences and indicators spread throughout a work rather than a half hour or more rest stop for budding romance and dance drama. Hundreds of pages are dispensed with in the first fifteen minutes and this makes it all the more painful that so much of the melodrama is retained. The Flesh, Blood and Bone ceremony is well done but the obligatory meeting with Dumbledore is too much neglected. However, the film does treat the character of Amos better, giving him some real emotional punch when Cedric's body is returned. Book >>>>> Movie

Now this where the series really took hold of me both in the books and film.

Starting off really really creepy, we are then wisked off to the vibrant Quidditch World Cup then suddenly Death Eaters strike, proving that no where is safe in the wizarding world

Essentially "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" is a dark/highschool/sports movie, the Tri-Wizard Tornament is upon Hogwarts meaning that foreign students are also joining the school and the tradition of the Yule Ball.

Everything looks stunning, every competition takes a phobia and makes it so tense it questions all senses, Harry especially for not only does he have to deal with premonitions, but also life and death (Against the Dragon), compassion and selflessness (In the Waters) and right and wrong (In the Maze).

And finally the ressurection of Voldermort, me walking into the movie and not having any prior knowledge how events would turn i was surprised to finally see everything not tidy and happily wrapped up, the first time the future of Harry's life looked uncertain.

Cedirc Diggory is added to the mix and to be honest i really enjoyed Robert Pattison's performance, not knowing that he would eventually be "Edward Cullen" i still enjoy the actor (It is reported that Robert hates the Edward Character, finally some sense from that Vampire cast), Brendan Gleeson as Mad-Eye Moody was brilliant fun, and let's face it Ralph Fiennes plays a chilling Voldermort.

Final Verdict: "Everything is about to change", the films original Tagline lives to it's statement and so much more, I give it a 10/10 for finally capturing my interest in the Novels.
